ticket.title: Add limit functionality to find first and last
ticket.original-body:
The convenience methods @.first@ and @.last@ on @ActiveRecord::Base@ have had me itching to pass in an integer limit as you can with @Array#first@ and @#last@. E.g.,
@@@ ruby array = [1, 2, "buckle", :my, Shoe] array.first # => 1 array.first(2) # => [1, 2] array.first(1) # => [1] array.last(2) # => [:my, Shoe]
Attached is a patch that adds this functionality.
@@@ ruby Person.first # => #<Person id: 1> Person.first(2) # => [#<Person id: 1>, #<Person id: 2>] Person.first(1) # => [#<Person id: 1>] Person.last(2) # => [#<Person id: 49>, #<Person id: 50>] @@@
Considerations:
It made the most sense to add logic through to @ActiveRecord.find_initial@, rather than merely to the convenience, surface methods, but this obviously could cause problems for those who have been blindly passing options hashes to @find(:first)@ and @:last@ that include a @:limit@. I'm open to the idea of a less-invasive approach that merely adds the functionality to the convenience methods, but this seemed less desirable and messier.
If this is of interest to others, it could also be added to @ActiveResource::Base@.
ticket.latest-body:
The convenience methods @.first@ and @.last@ on @ActiveRecord::Base@ have had me itching to pass in an integer limit as you can with @Array#first@ and @#last@. E.g.,
@@@ ruby array = [1, 2, "buckle", :my, Shoe] array.first # => 1 array.first(2) # => [1, 2] array.first(1) # => [1] array.last(2) # => [:my, Shoe]
Attached is a patch that adds this functionality.
@@@ ruby Person.first # => #<Person id: 1> Person.first(2) # => [#<Person id: 1>, #<Person id: 2>] Person.first(1) # => [#<Person id: 1>] Person.last(2) # => [#<Person id: 49>, #<Person id: 50>] @@@
Considerations:
It made the most sense to add logic through to @ActiveRecord.find_initial@, rather than merely to the convenience, surface methods, but this obviously could cause problems for those who have been blindly passing options hashes to @find(:first)@ and @:last@ that include a @:limit@. I'm open to the idea of a less-invasive approach that merely adds the functionality to the convenience methods, but this seemed less desirable and messier.
If this is of interest to others, it could also be added to @ActiveResource::Base@.
ticket.original-body-html:
The convenience methods .first and .last on ActiveRecord::Base have had me itching to pass in an integer limit as you can with Array#first and #last. E.g.,

array = [1, 2, "buckle", :my, Shoe]
array.first    # => 1
array.first(2) # => [1, 2]
array.first(1) # => [1]
array.last(2)  # => [:my, Shoe]

Attached is a patch that adds this functionality.

Person.first # => #
Person.first(2) # => [#, #]
Person.first(1) # => [#]
Person.last(2) # => [#, #]


Considerations:







It made the most sense to add logic through to @ActiveRecord.find_initial@, rather than merely to the convenience, surface methods, but this obviously could cause problems for those who have been blindly passing options hashes to @find(:first)@ and @:last@ that include a @:limit@. I'm open to the idea of a less-invasive approach that merely adds the functionality to the convenience methods, but this seemed less desirable and messier.







If this is of interest to others, it could also be added to @ActiveResource::Base@.

version.body:
The convenience methods @.first@ and @.last@ on @ActiveRecord::Base@ have had me itching to pass in an integer limit as you can with @Array#first@ and @#last@. E.g.,
@@@ ruby array = [1, 2, "buckle", :my, Shoe] array.first # => 1 array.first(2) # => [1, 2] array.first(1) # => [1] array.last(2) # => [:my, Shoe] @@@
Attached is a patch that adds this functionality.
@@@ ruby Person.first # => #<Person id: 1> Person.first(2) # => [#<Person id: 1>, #<Person id: 2>] Person.first(1) # => [#<Person id: 1>] Person.last(2) # => [#<Person id: 49>, #<Person id: 50>] @@@
Considerations:
ActiveRecord::Base subclasses are not kinds of Array, but named scopes and association proxies come closer. Consider the following:
@@@ ruby >> Person.scoped({}).first # SELECT * FROM `people` LIMIT 1 => #<Person> >> Person.scoped({}).first(2) # SELECT * FROM `people` => [#<Person>, #<Person>] @@@
The first gets special treatment. The second does not. In order to make the second consistent, it only makes sense to add the behavior to @ActiveRecord::Base@ as well. (Named scope functionality requires additions to this patch, but I'd prefer a consensus before making any more changes.)
Additionally, it made the most sense to add logic through to @ActiveRecord.find_initial@, rather than merely to the convenience, surface methods, but this obviously could cause problems for those who have been blindly passing options hashes to @find(:first)@ and @:last@ that include a @:limit@. I'm open to the idea of a less-invasive approach that merely adds the functionality to the convenience methods, but this seemed less desirable and messier.
If this is of interest to others, it could also be added to @ActiveResource::Base@.
version.body-html:
The convenience methods .first and .last on ActiveRecord::Base have had me itching to pass in an integer limit as you can with Array#first and #last. E.g.,

array = [1, 2, "buckle", :my, Shoe]
array.first    # => 1
array.first(2) # => [1, 2]
array.first(1) # => [1]
array.last(2)  # => [:my, Shoe]

Attached is a patch that adds this functionality.

Person.first    # => #<Person id: 1>
Person.first(2) # => [#<Person id: 1>, #<Person id: 2>]
Person.first(1) # => [#<Person id: 1>]
Person.last(2)  # => [#<Person id: 49>, #<Person id: 50>]

Considerations:

ActiveRecord::Base subclasses are not kinds of Array, but named scopes and association proxies come closer. Consider the following:

>> Person.scoped({}).first    # SELECT * FROM `people` LIMIT 1
=> #<Person>
>> Person.scoped({}).first(2) # SELECT * FROM `people`
=> [#<Person>, #<Person>]

The first gets special treatment. The second does not. In order to make the second consistent, it only makes sense to add the behavior to ActiveRecord::Base as well. (Named scope functionality requires additions to this patch, but I'd prefer a consensus before making any more changes.)

Additionally, it made the most sense to add logic through to @ActiveRecord.find_initial@, rather than merely to the convenience, surface methods, but this obviously could cause problems for those who have been blindly passing options hashes to find(:first) and :last that include a :limit. I'm open to the idea of a less-invasive approach that merely adds the functionality to the convenience methods, but this seemed less desirable and messier.

If this is of interest to others, it could also be added to ActiveResource::Base.

version.body: Does not appear to be in place in 3.0.0: @@@ % rails c Loading development environment (Rails 3.0.0) ruby-1.9.2-p0 > User.first 2 User Load (0.2ms) SELECT `users`.* FROM `users` => [] ruby-1.9.2-p0 > User.last 2 User Load (0.3ms) SELECT `users`.* FROM `users` => [] @@@
version.body-html:
Does not appear to be in place in 3.0.0:

% rails c
Loading development environment (Rails 3.0.0)
ruby-1.9.2-p0 > User.first 2
  User Load (0.2ms)  SELECT users. FROM users
 => []
ruby-1.9.2-p0 > User.last 2
  User Load (0.3ms)  SELECT users. FROM users
 => []

version.title: Add limit functionality to find first and last

version.body-html:
@stephen, patch also does not apply cleanly anymore since there has been much refactoring around ARel.

I misread the second half of your OP and looked on the net result ( which works ) but the query does not since it does not use limit but gets all and then pick n from array.

Feel free to submit another patch.
version.title: Add limit functionality to find first and last

version.body: Makes sense that the Rails default would fetch all and select back n accordingly, proper SQL query should be implemented on the adapter level since it involves different syntax for each DBMS.
version.body-html: Makes sense that the Rails default would fetch all and select back n accordingly, proper SQL query should be implemented on the adapter level since it involves different syntax for each DBMS.
version.title: Add limit functionality to find first and last

version.body:
I'm happy to fix the patch if there's interest in getting this into Rails.
@Elad, I'm not sure what you're saying. The Rails default for ActiveRecord::Base.first is to fetch one record from the database (with :limit => 1). As soon as you add a numeric argument, however, it fetches all, which is not what I would have expected. The only case I can think of where .first(n) would fetch all is ActiveRecord::Base.all.first(n), because .all returns an Array.
version.body-html:
I'm happy to fix the patch if there's interest in getting this into Rails.

@Elad, I'm not sure what you're saying. The Rails default for ActiveRecord::Base.first is to fetch one record from the database (with :limit => 1). As soon as you add a numeric argument, however, it fetches all, which is not what I would have expected. The only case I can think of where .first(n) would fetch all is ActiveRecord::Base.all.first(n), because .all returns an Array.
version.title: Add limit functionality to find first and last

version.body: This supra footwear is called a modern vintage and has been since their introduction in 2003 where they began in Europe. Every supra shoes has some type of ornament, adornment or hardware and is comprised of aged leather that is bought from around the world. These supra uk are culturally engaging and allow for the woman wearing them to be enveloped in luxury.With new cuts and styles and hand stitched shoes, these timberland boots, heels or flats will make every foot look like it stepped out of vintage Hollywood. This timberland shoes have been worn and coveted by many of the most famous females in recent history. One such coach outlet, Jennifer Aniston, wears them in public and at home.This company makes many different unique styles of bags outlet from ankle booties to sandals, pumps, moncler jackets online, platforms and wedges. One louis vuitton bag in particular is ideal for the gothic style sense; it is patent leather and laces up the front of the shaft. There are also zippers on each side, and this shoe offers a flat heel of a half inch.Another great moncler jackets sale is featured in People's Style Watch and is called a platform bootie. This ture religion jeans has a raised panel in front of the ankle as well as a heel that measures 4.5 inches. The front offers a leather bandage appearance and is considered high fashion.
